abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rural Financial Services
            Project for Ghana were as follows: outcome was moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: innovations should be vetted through pilot
            and stakeholder consultations to ensure suitability for the
            local context. A pilot for the formal and informal linkage
            program will have highlighted implementation challenges,
            which can then have been addressed before scaling up.
            Widening financial intermediation by reaching new markets or
            sectors requires appropriate strategies or innovative
            products that address these markets. The design of an
            effective training program requires clear identification of
            the content of the training to be imparted, the capacity of
            trainers, and who and how many will be trained. Despite
            regular policy dialogue, the project team on its own was not
            successful in reducing subsidies even though directed credit
            and subsidies had a direct bearing on the project's
            intermediate objective of financial widening and deepening.
            The shortage of measurable indicators and an appropriate
            monitoring and evaluation (M and E) system can reduce a
            project's ability to make timely corrections as well as
            to track its impact. Project teams should be careful to
            avoid project development objectives that are too general to
            be effectively monitored.
